title: Loch Coruisk Walking Route

images.title: Martin Thackeray / Boulders next to Loch Coruisk
images.caption: Surrounded by the Cuillin Hills on the Isle of Skye, Loch Coruisk. is one of my favourite locations in the whole of the British Isles. There are no roads here. You get there by foot or by boat.

images.title: John Allan / Cooling down in Loch Coruisk
images.caption: Cooling down in Loch Coruisk. A pair of deer, oblivious to the photographer, enjoying a paddle in the loch on a warm May afternoon.

images.title: Donald MacDonald / Loch na Cuilce and Loch Coruisk from Sgurr na Stri, Skye
images.caption: Loch na Cuilce and Loch Coruisk from Sgurr na Stri, Skye.

images.title: Angus / The Cuillin and Loch Coruisk
images.caption: The Cuillin and Loch Coruisk. A view taken from Sgurr na Stri looking along the ridge of Druim nan Ramh, with Loch Coruisk leading into the heart of the Black Cuillin.

images.title: John Allan / Boulder near the head of Loch Coruisk
images.caption: Boulder near the head of the loch. The view beyond is towards the upper part of Coir' Uisge and the Cuillin Ridge.

images.title: Ben Brooksbank / The Cuillin from Loch na Cuilce
images.caption: Cuillin Hills from the loch Coruisk. View NW from a boat: Sgùrr na Banachdaich (3,167 ft.), Sgùrr a' Ghreadaidh (3,192 ft.), to Bruach na Frithe (3,143 ft.).

description: This circular hike takes you around the stunning Loch Coruisk in the Cullin Hills on the Isle of Skye. It's a remote spot with some fairly rugged paths surrounding the isolated loch.  Legend has it that the fresh water loch is the home of a kelpie or water horse, a shape-shifting creature that can assume human form. The site is located south of Sligachan and north of Elgol. If you head north west of the loch you could visit another of the area's highlights at the delightful Fairy Pools .
